Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Kathryn Riley of Wake Forest University to conduct a research project, entitled "Simplifying detection of microbes using nanoparticles," during the summer of 2012 at Saitama University in Sakura-ku, Saitama, Japan. The host scientist is Dr. Shingo Saito.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the development of analytical methods using gold nana-particules to simplify the detection of microbes. The nano-particles interact with and differentiate between different microbial species and are then separated using electrically-driven separation methods.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Work at Saitama University involved the use of gold nanoparticles to facilitate the separation of microbes. Microbes, including bacteria, fungi, viruses and microscopic plants, are pervasive in the biosphere and have many functions. They play a role in many natural cycles and ecosystems; they are used in biotechnology; and they are used in the preparation of food and beverages. However, pathogenic microbes, like anthrax, can pose serious risks to human and animal life. Therefore, rapid and simple methods for the separation and sensitive detection of microbes and cells are of growing importance to the fields of food safety, homeland security, and environmental and human health assessment.

This research utilized the principles of electrophoresis—a separation technique driven by an applied electric field—to separate species based on their size and charge. Since microbes carry a net charge, either positive or negative depending upon the composition of the microbe surface, they can be analyzed by this technique. Traditionally, electrophoresis of microbes conducted in a capillary format (“capillary electrophoresis”) has resulted in the observation of multiple peaks for a single bacterial species, which makes it difficult to differentiate between multiple species in a complex sample. In this new work, a rapid and efficient method was developed for the detection of Saccharomyces cerevisiae (baker’s yeast) and Escherichia coli. Using modified gold nanoparticles as complexing agents for the bacteria, a single peak was observed for each of baker’s yeast and E.coli. These preliminary results suggest that this method will allow for the separation of multiple microbial species in complex mixtures. Future work will involve the application of these methods to a broader variety of bacteria and to mixtures of bacteria.

This work has shown promising evidence for the use of nanoparticles to improve upon existing methods for the detection of bacteria, like E. coli. The impacts of the research project include the development of new tools for chemists to study small molecules and microbes and the development of a rapid solution-based separation method to detect microbes. The continued development of this work will allow for the simultaneous detection of various microbial targets. In addition, this work will help to expand the use of nanomaterials for chemistry-related applications. Ultimately, this work will have a range of potential clinical and environmental applications and as a result, will broadly impact a multidisciplinary community spanning the fields of chemistry, physics, cancer biology, bacteriology, and nanoscience.

Additionally, this project supported the research of a second year graduate student in chemistry who is a member of an underrepresented minority group. The student acquired new technical and research skills during the course of this fellowship, which, coupled with a positive experience working in the host institution in Japan, have equipped the student to establish additional international collaborations in her future career.
